moves.1. e4: I’m black here, and Alex starts of with the King Pawn Opening.
moves.2. f4: King’s Gambit. Risky for white because it opens up their kingside.
moves.2... Bc5: A perfectly fine move stopping white from castling kingside (the bishop is guarding g1). Also, note that if 3. fxe5, black responds with 3. ... Qh4+! 4. g3 (if 4. Ke2 Qxe4#) Qxe4 and black wins the rook.
moves.3. Nf3: Preventing Qh4 and attacking e5 again.
moves.5. Bxf7+: The point here is to check on g5 after Kxf7, but this trap actually does not work, due to the next moves.
moves.5... Kxf7 6. Ng5+: It seems like black’s LSB is gone, but...
moves.6... Qxg5: Boom! And now white is in a pickle.
moves.7. fxg5 Bxd1: I’m up by 2 points after Kxe1.
moves.20... Rf1+ 21. Ke2: I could have took the bishop here.
moves.21... Rf2+ 22. Kd1 Rxg2: Up by 5, but it could have been 7, with Rf1, followed by Rxc1. But that removes the whole rook on 2nd effect.
moves.23. d3: Seriously? Now the knight is free.
moves.26. Bd2: At this point, Alex resigned, but this is what it would be like if he didn’t...
